items.author: BBC
items.content: This is one of the truly outstanding works of post-war European cinema.

items.author: Peter Bradshaw
items.content: A wonderfully composed movie in which Ingmar Bergman is able to vary the tone from melancholy to gaiety in the most deeply satisfying way

items.author: TV Guide Magazine
items.content: Possibly Ingmar Bergman's finest film and a landmark in film history.

items.author: Josh Larsen
items.content: The bitter has not yet overpowered the sweet in this early film from writer-director Ingmar Bergman.

items.author: Chuck Bowen
items.content: Initially, Wild Strawberries appears to be an almost pointedly unsubtle coming-of-age story that’s been goosed with dime-store surrealism and male handwringing masked as intellectual engagement with humankind. But the bluntness is a misdirection that underlines the depth of Bergman’s empathy with his hero as well as his dedication to his real subject, which is the process of mentally freeing oneself from an insidiously limiting self-mythology.

items.author: Ty Burr
items.content: A film that goes where many others have gone (yes, this is Scrooge for Ph.D.s) but with a subtlety few have dreamed of?

items.author: Dave Kehr
items.content: There's a lot of allegorical baggage on board, but the film's virtues lie in its relative simplicity.
It's an occasionally over-symbolic work (most notably in the opening nightmare sequence), but it's filled with richly observed characters and a real feeling for the joys of nature and youth.

items.author: Total Film
items.content: For those who think legendary cine-Swede Ingmar Bergman's films are aloof and coldly austere, this warm, welcoming 1957 road movie of aged reflection - the inspiration for Woody Allen's Deconstructing Harry - might come as a surprise.

items.author: Bosley Crowther
items.content: This one is so thoroughly mystifying that we wonder whether Mr. Bergman himself knew what he was trying to say.
